abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about the
            Albania Natural Resources Development Project. Forests cover
            more than 50 percent of Albania’s surface area. Following
            roughly two decades of transition, illegal logging, and
            overgrazing of forests and pasture lands, Albanians living
            in rural areas started to become conscious of the damaging
            effects these practices were having on the environment.
            Participatory planning and management of forest and pasture
            lands was piloted in 30 communes during the implementation
            of the Albanian Forestry Project financed by the World Bank
            in 1996. Given its positive outcome and wide community
            support, the approach was extended under the National
            Resource Development Project in more than 200 communes. This
            experience led to the decision of the government of Albania
            in June 2008 to formalize forest land rights transfers to
            345 communes, resources which are used by almost one million
            people. The project had addressed the issues of soil
            degradation and improved watersheds. More sustainable,
            community-based natural resource management in Albania will
            lead to enhanced productivity, incomes, and, overall,
            improvements in land and water resources for the public
            sector. The investments have helped to support increases in
            income earned from forest and agricultural activities in
            communal areas and a significant reduction in erosion, and
            Albania is one of the first countries to sequester carbon on
            eroded lands through the BioCarbon Fund.
